title: 115_hr5101
content: The Act is titled the "Kleptocracy Asset Recovery Rewards Act". It includes findings and expresses the sense of Congress. The Stolen Asset Recovery Initiative estimates that $20-40 billion is lost annually to corruption in developing countries. In 2014, $480 million in corruption proceeds hidden by former Nigerian dictator Sani Abacha was forfeited. The Department of Justice established the Kleptocracy Asset Recovery Initiative in 2010 to forfeit proceeds of foreign corruption and return them to benefit those harmed. Only about $5 billion of the $20-40 billion lost annually to corruption in developing countries has been repatriated in the last 15 years. Corruption weakens governments, reducing resources for fighting terrorism and building strong institutions. The United States has effective programs to reward individuals who assist in identifying and convicting criminals and seizing illicit assets. The Internal Revenue Service and the Department of State have programs to reward individuals for providing information on illicit activities. However, there are no specific programs that offer monetary incentives for identifying and recovering stolen assets related to foreign government corruption. Foreign government corruption involves officials stealing, misappropriating, or diverting assets for personal gain through embezzlement or bribes. Recovery of stolen assets may not always lead to forfeiture actions, hindering the ability to pay rewards under existing Treasury Department authorities. Officials take bribes to allow government resources to be expended in ways that lack transparency. They often use the US and international financial system to hide stolen assets. Whistleblowers who expose foreign corruption face risks to their safety and need incentives like monetary rewards and asylum to protect themselves and their families. It is the sense of Congress that a Department of the Treasury stolen asset recovery rewards program is needed to intensify the global fight against corruption and help identify and recover stolen assets linked to foreign government corruption. The program aims to forfeit proceeds of corruption and return stolen assets to the affected countries. A Department of the Treasury stolen asset recovery rewards program is needed to intensify the global fight against corruption and help identify and recover stolen assets linked to foreign government corruption. The program aims to forfeit proceeds of corruption and return stolen assets to the affected countries. SEC. 3. IN GENERAL. The Department of the Treasury Kleptocracy Asset Recovery Rewards Program is established to support U.S. Government efforts in restraining, seizing, forfeiting, or repatriating stolen assets related to foreign government corruption. Administered by the Secretary, the program aims to combat global corruption and return stolen assets to affected countries. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with relevant departments, may pay rewards for information leading to the restraining or seizure of stolen assets in U.S. financial institutions or in the possession of U.S. persons. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with relevant departments, may pay rewards for information leading to the restraining or seizure of stolen assets in U.S. financial institutions or in the possession of U.S. persons, including forfeiture and repatriation of assets. Coordination is ensured to avoid duplication or interference with other authorized payments for obtaining information. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with relevant departments, establishes procedures for offering, administering, and paying rewards for information leading to actions such as asset seizure. Approval from the Attorney General is required before offering rewards in matters under Federal criminal jurisdiction. The Secretary of the Treasury must obtain the Attorney General's approval for offering rewards in cases under Federal criminal jurisdiction. $450,000 is authorized for rewards in fiscal year 2019, with a limit of $25,000,000 per year unless waived by the President with 30 days notice to Congress. The Secretary must obtain approval from the Attorney General for offering rewards in Federal criminal cases. Rewards under this section cannot exceed $5,000,000 unless personally authorized by the Secretary. Payments for rewards should be made using recovered stolen assets before using appropriated funds. Information submitted for rewards must be under penalty of perjury. The Secretary can offer a reward of a greater amount in exceptional cases with approval and certification required. Protection measures for the recipient's identity can be taken if necessary. The Secretary may provide a monetary reward for information protection. Government officials are ineligible for rewards if they provide information while on duty. Individuals involved in criminal activities cannot claim rewards. The Secretary may reduce or deny rewards for individuals involved in criminal conduct or corruption. The Secretary's determinations under this section are final and not subject to judicial review. The Secretary is required to issue a report detailing stolen assets to Congress within 180 days of enactment and annually thereafter. The Secretary must report stolen assets in the United States and efforts to identify more assets and their owners. Discussions with international financial institutions are included to locate stolen assets held outside the US. The Secretary must report stolen assets in the United States and efforts to identify more assets and their owners, including discussions with international financial institutions outside the US. The report shall exclude information on ongoing investigations. Definitions for "appropriate committees of the Congress" and "financial asset" are provided.
